quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we dive deep into Lauryn's favorite topic, onboarding, why it's one of the biggest and most undervalued growth levers, what she's learned about optimizing onboarding flow through her work redoing Airtable's onboarding flow, what she's seen work and common pitfalls around onboarding, plus a ton of advice around figuring out your activation metric.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames onboarding as a major (and often overlooked) growth lever and highlights activation metrics as a key focus area.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Treasure yields are at a 15-year high, but buying US Treasuries is super complicated if you go to a bank or navigate an ancient government website, or at least that was the case.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete data point (“15-year high”) paired with a practical friction insight about why a seemingly good option isn’t widely used.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Now you can move your cash into US Treasuries with the flexibility of a bank account, you can access your cash whenever you want, even before your Treasury bills hit maturity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a product positioning/UX insight: removing liquidity constraints can make a traditionally rigid financial product feel like a bank account.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There are no hold periods, no settlement days, just a safe place to park your cash and earn a reliable yield.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of value props that reduce user friction—useful as a template for clear benefit-led messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Treasure yields are at a 15-year high, but buying US Treasuries is super complicated if you go to a bank or navigate an ancient government website, or at least that was the case.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a timely macro data point (15-year high yields) and the practical friction that prevents people from acting on it.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can move your cash into US Treasuries with the flexibility of a bank account, you can access your cash whenever you want, even before your Treasury bills hit maturity.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: treat Treasuries as a liquid cash-management tool rather than a locked-up investment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There are no hold periods, no settlement days, just a safe place to park your cash and earn a reliable yield.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable, practical checklist of what to look for in a cash parking option (liquidity + simplicity + yield).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For example, in Miro, you can build out your product strategy by brainstorming with sticky notes, comments, live reactions, voting tool, even an estimation app to scope out your team sprints.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Concrete workflow for turning collaborative ideation into prioritization and sprint scoping using specific tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And with one of Miro's ready-made template, you can go from discovery and research to product roadmap to customer journey flows, final mocks, you get the picture.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A lightweight end-to-end product development flow that teams can replicate using templates to reduce process overhead.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test everything
quotes.text: I find that there's generally two reasons why a grow team wants to experiment, and one of them is to understand more precisely the metric impact of what they're building and what they're putting in front of customers, and the other is risk mitigation where you're making so many big dramatic changes that there's some risk that while this could be really great for the business, it could also be really bad and it would be good to understand that before everybody's experiencing that in production.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Provides a clear two-part framework for deciding why (and whether) to run experiments.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test everything
quotes.text: So, with that framework in mind, sometimes you don't need to experiment.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concise, countercultural reminder that experimentation isn’t always the default best practice.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test everything
quotes.text: Sometimes if the business, let's say activation, right, activation rates go up 6% versus 7%, that precision actually doesn't help all that much beyond being able to say in your performance review, "Hey, I increased activation by 7%."
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Challenges the value of marginal metric precision when it doesn’t change decisions, only reporting/credit.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test everything
quotes.text: So, with all that said, generally my advice is to experiment when you need to and to primarily see it as a risk mitigation tactic when you're making dramatic changes and to let the product development process do more work.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat experiments as risk management for big bets rather than a default workflow step.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test everything
quotes.text: So, spend more time with customers, be more rigorous in understanding precisely what problem you're solving, get mocks in front of people and see how they react, and hopefully have more conviction than you otherwise would when you ship something that it's okay if every customer sees it tomorrow and that the experiment doesn't actually matter as much.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Offers a practical alternative to A/B testing: customer understanding + problem rigor + mock testing to ship with conviction.

quotes.topic_title: Building a culture beyond experiment metrics
quotes.text: However, I do think you can build a different culture, and the only way to escape the trap of experimenting everything is to have a very intentional culture about doing right by customers and doing the right thing for the business.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A clear cultural prescription: counterbalance experiment obsession by explicitly prioritizing customer and business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Building a culture beyond experiment metrics
quotes.text: A growth team or a growth org exists in service of improving the business and delivering results for the business, and whether or not you measure those precisely in an A/B test, you still shipped them or you didn't.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Reframes growth work around shipping real outcomes, not just what can be cleanly measured in experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Building a culture beyond experiment metrics
quotes.text: So, the rigor around your process was either there or it wasn't.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A memorable standard for evaluating teams: judge the quality of the process, not only the metric movement.

quotes.topic_title: Building a culture beyond experiment metrics
quotes.text: So, a culture around the impact you had on customers as measured by qualitative feedback or as measured by deals that were closed or deals that weren't lost, or other kinds of indicators that you did the right thing for customers is important and there shouldn't be, especially in engineering within the world of growth, a culture around having to point to numbers to demonstrate your impact because if there is, then the team will biased experiments all the time, and that's not necessarily the right thing for the business.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on alternative impact signals (qual + revenue retention) and a warning about metric-driven incentives skewing behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Building a culture beyond experiment metrics
quotes.text: It's a very expensive cost.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A succinct reminder that over-experimentation and biased testing can impose significant business and opportunity costs.

quotes.topic_title: Example: Shipping Airtable Forms without testing
quotes.text: We created that feature which as a result was gated on creating an account with Airtable, and we just turned it on and wanted to see what would happen because we knew from rigor of a wonderful product team doing robust customer analysis and also doing the data work that this is something that people wanted, that it was a feature that would bring value to customers, and that even if it didn't move certain metrics like a signup percentage, even if it might affect the mix shift of activation rate from folks who signed up, it would be net good for customers who were using forms and who were submitting them.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concrete example of skipping an A/B test when customer research and product value are strong, even if metric impacts are uncertain.

quotes.topic_title: Example: Shipping Airtable Forms without testing
quotes.text: So, we did roll that one out without an A/B test. It did have a big enough impact on our signup metrics that we saw at top line and didn't need the A/B test to see what was happening.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Shows a practical heuristic: if the effect is large and obvious in top-line metrics, an experiment may be unnecessary.

quotes.topic_title: Example: Shipping Airtable Forms without testing
quotes.text: And we also were able to use attribution to make some analysis possible after we rolled it out so we could learn from what was happening to the base afterward.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Highlights a methodology for learning post-launch via attribution when you choose not to run a controlled test.

quotes.topic_title: Example: Shipping Airtable Forms without testing
quotes.text: I think it does, and it also cannot be an excuse for rigor around building well and being precise in what customers need, but overall, if you can be a results-oriented organization that just wants to do the right thing and move with urgency, then in my opinion, that's the way that you can have the most impact.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Balances speed with rigor: moving fast without experiments still requires precision on customer needs and quality execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why onboarding is a major growth lever
quotes.text: retention ends up being the thing you got to crack. If you can't crack retention, nothing else matters.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: focus on retention as the foundational metric before other growth efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Why onboarding is a major growth lever
quotes.text: onboarding ends up being one of the biggest levers to increasing retention which basically A then B equal C, onboarding ends up being one of the biggest areas of opportunity for growth teams both early on and late stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A causal mental model linking onboarding improvements directly to retention and broad growth impact across company stages.

quotes.topic_title: Why onboarding is a major growth lever
quotes.text: Not every business should prioritize onboarding first, but if you have some sort of self-serve element of your product, if someone can give your product a try, maybe you have a playground or a sandbox demo, if there's a premium element to your pricing scheme, if you maybe offer things totally for free and don't even have monetization yet, onboarding is that first really important choke point that from which downstream of onboarding so many important metrics and results flow for the business, from converting someone to a paid customer to closing a deal to growing, how many people in an organization are using your product.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A practical applicability filter: onboarding becomes the key growth choke point in self-serve/freemium/trial contexts because it drives conversion, sales, and expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Why onboarding is a major growth lever
quotes.text: So, all of that really comes back to onboarding and if you can get that right, lots of good things will follow.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A succinct guiding principle that frames onboarding quality as a leading indicator for multiple downstream outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable onboarding rebuild: wizard, personalization, education
quotes.text: we've built an immersive wizard that we called Guided Onboarding that helped guide you through setting up your first workflow on Airtable, and in doing that reduced the cognitive load of getting started, helped you make more progress faster, and created scaffolding that more than 90% of customers would benefit from to be able to get up and running on a product that's pretty complicated.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concrete onboarding pattern (guided wizard) tied to clear outcomes (reduced cognitive load, faster progress) and a specific adoption claim (>90% benefit).

quotes.topic_title: Airtable onboarding rebuild: wizard, personalization, education
quotes.text: We also then introduced some personalization to use case on top of that. So, instead of helping you build something generic, having you build something that's relevant to you.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Highlights a practical shift from generic onboarding to use-case personalization to increase relevance and momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable onboarding rebuild: wizard, personalization, education
quotes.text: And then we also worked on ongoing education. So, once you're in a workflow, once you've built something, how do we help you level it up to go from beginner to intermediate to advanced?
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Frames onboarding as a continuous education ladder rather than a one-time setup moment.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable onboarding rebuild: wizard, personalization, education
quotes.text: We did retire a bunch of our tooltips which were a big part of onboarding for a really long time.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive move away from tooltip-heavy onboarding, implying higher-leverage patterns replaced them.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable onboarding rebuild: wizard, personalization, education
quotes.text: In general, tried to take a portfolio approach to what we did.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Suggests managing onboarding improvements as a mix of big bets and incremental optimizations rather than a single initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Impact and what made guided onboarding work
quotes.text: Overall, the investments we made in onboarding over about a six to eight month period that included the wizard, The Mole with ongoing education, and also some personalization together drove a 20% lift in activation rate for Airtable.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Concrete data point tying a multi-pronged onboarding program to a meaningful activation lift over a defined timeframe.

quotes.topic_title: Impact and what made guided onboarding work
quotes.text: I think it speaks to the importance of really understanding what a user needs to be onboarded well, which is not the same as what your business wants the user to be onboarded to. So, delineating those and building carefully is really what made it successful.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A practical mental model: separate user needs from business priorities to design onboarding that actually activates users.

quotes.topic_title: Impact and what made guided onboarding work
quotes.text: I would say that the guided onboarding wizard which is the immersive wizard that helps you figure out how to get started was the most impactful thing we did.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Highlights which intervention mattered most, helping practitioners prioritize immersive guided onboarding over smaller tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Impact and what made guided onboarding work
quotes.text: I'm not sure that this pattern is one that works for every product. I think it's one that works well for a complicated product, where figuring out where to go next and how to get started is actually very challenging or has a high cognitive load.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Clear applicability rule: immersive wizards are especially effective when cognitive load is high and next steps are unclear.

quotes.topic_title: Impact and what made guided onboarding work
quotes.text: However, users don't necessarily need to get that started on day one. They don't need to learn about the advanced stuff when they haven't even looked at a workflow before.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive prioritization: delay advanced features and focus onboarding on foundational workflows first.

quotes.topic_title: Personalization: segment by learning and building style
quotes.text: when we rolled out the guided onboarding wizard, it was actually just one generic onboarding that was one-size-fits-all, and while escape patches are great, we felt like we could solve, as I think I referenced earlier, more than 90% of use cases or users needs with one generic onboarding to start and then we could personalize from there.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A pragmatic rollout strategy: start with a broadly effective default flow before investing in deeper personalization.

quotes.topic_title: Personalization: segment by learning and building style
quotes.text: When we started to personalize, generally we found bucketing customers by their learning style and their building style was more effective than more classic segmentation, like do you work in marketing, do you work in product management, do you work in operation.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive segmentation framework that prioritizes how users learn/build over their job function.

quotes.topic_title: Personalization: segment by learning and building style
quotes.text: Knowing how someone would go about building was more effective than what do you actually want to see on the other side.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for onboarding: optimize for the user's process, not just their desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Personalization: segment by learning and building style
quotes.text: So, actually getting that data in the flow is really useful because then we can route customers to a fully different experience.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to collect intent/context during signup so you can dynamically route users into distinct onboarding paths.

quotes.topic_title: Personalization: segment by learning and building style
quotes.text: It's amazing how much low-hanging fruit there is to personalize and segment that onboarding experience in so many products that are out there. You just need to be really detail-oriented and precise on who you're working with.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A strong reminder that meaningful onboarding gains often come from careful, precise segmentation rather than big redesigns.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing activation metrics: week-four multi-user active
quotes.text: So, overall, every growth team needs a north star metric. It's so important to have singular focus on what the business results are that you are working to drive in your team.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A clear principle for aligning onboarding/activation work around a single outcome metric tied to business results.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing activation metrics: week-four multi-user active
quotes.text: For us, that was week four, multi-user, meaning in the fourth week, more than one person on that team is active and contributing to a workflow on Airtable.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concrete example of an activation definition that bakes in time, collaboration, and meaningful usage rather than early clicks.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing activation metrics: week-four multi-user active
quotes.text: This metric is something that our wonderful analytics team determined to be highly correlated with long-term retention.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A reminder that activation metrics should be chosen based on demonstrated correlation to long-term retention, not intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing activation metrics: week-four multi-user active
quotes.text: In general, I think an activation rate that falls in a lower percentage range, maybe for most companies five to 15%, is better than one that falls in a higher percentage range because it means that there's likely much higher correlation with long-term retention and you're really working hard to get most of your users to reach a state that they're not reaching today.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive heuristic: prefer a harder activation bar if it’s more predictive of retention and creates meaningful headroom for improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing activation metrics: week-four multi-user active
quotes.text: I would much prefer to pick a more specific, more precise metric that maybe only 5% of users reach, but know that those 5% of users will be with us for the long haul, and if we could get that 5% even to 6% or 7%, it would have huge downstream effects on long-term metrics for the business.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A practical growth model: choose a highly predictive activation metric even if it’s low-volume, because small lifts can compound into large retention gains.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing activation: decomposing and adding supporting metrics
quotes.text: So, one of the first things that we did when me and my team started to revisit week four multi-user active right before we started to rebuild onboarding is break that metric down into all of its component.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A practical methodology: decompose a top-line activation metric into its underlying parts before redesigning onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing activation: decomposing and adding supporting metrics
quotes.text: Doing that really detailed work on the metric helped us understand what levers we could pull to have a really big impact on activation overall.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Highlights why metric decomposition is useful: it reveals controllable levers that drive the outcome metric.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing activation: decomposing and adding supporting metrics
quotes.text: The reason why we added these metrics is we were building new mechanisms for onboarding that were helping users build more effectively and find more value in Airtable, but sometimes those treatments helped users become more sophisticated but didn't help them invite more teammates, or sometimes those new mechanisms made someone more interested in giving us a shot for a few more weeks, but what they built was actually not any more impressive than if they had done it on their own.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concrete example of tradeoffs: onboarding changes can improve one dimension (sophistication/retention) while failing on another (team invites/build quality).

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing activation: decomposing and adding supporting metrics
quotes.text: So, this group of metrics actually really set us free.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: adding metrics (instead of simplifying to one) can improve decision-making during major onboarding changes.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing activation: decomposing and adding supporting metrics
quotes.text: So, I know it's a little unconventional to have a few metrics that you work with, but we did find that that was really helpful when we were making big changes.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: use a small set of complementary metrics to evaluate onboarding when a single activation metric is incomplete.

quotes.topic_title: Workspace vs user activation, and changing north stars
quotes.text: In the case of Airtable, which is a product that has seat-based pricing and generally horizontal adoption, it totally makes sense to have a workspace activation measure because you want to understand in an account, in an organization how many folks are actually using a product and finding value.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A clear rule-of-thumb for when workspace/team activation is the right lens (seat-based, horizontally adopted collaboration products).

quotes.topic_title: Workspace vs user activation, and changing north stars
quotes.text: it's important that growth teams are agile and this means that north stars, key metrics, focus metrics will change, and if you're working on the same metric forever, there's probably some inefficiency in actually chasing the biggest impact for the business.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that sticking with one “perfect” north star too long can reduce business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Workspace vs user activation, and changing north stars
quotes.text: So, I would be open-minded about if a workspace or team or account activation metric is always the right thing to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Practical guidance to periodically reassess whether your current activation metric is still the best focus.

quotes.topic_title: Workspace vs user activation, and changing north stars
quotes.text: Stability in metric is great, it helps with momentum, it helps with building expertise, but sometimes we overfocus on picking the perfect north star metric and by the time you feel like you've found the perfect one, it's actually time to move on to something different and work on a different opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: metric stability has benefits, but optimizing for “perfect” can cause you to miss the next highest-leverage opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is necessary, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern growth stacks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of poor experimentation infrastructure and mismatched tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of an analysis methodology (segmentation) that helps teams interpret experiment results more effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics and then set you to north star metrics, like activation, retention, subscriptions, and payments,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages a measurement framework shift from shallow metrics to business-outcome “north star” metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting Airtable growth focus from revenue to users
quotes.text: Roughly the arc of that change for us was shifting from being a growth org focused on revenue to a growth organization focused on user growth and customer growth.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A concrete example of an org-level north star pivot that reoriented multiple teams from short-term revenue to long-term user/customer growth.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting Airtable growth focus from revenue to users
quotes.text: This for us was a really important moment where we decided that it was most essential in our work to grow the business to bring millions more people onto the platform, using the product and finding value in the product, because we were taking a decade's long view that they could always become monetized or converted customers later, and there wasn't really a rush.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A counterintuitive long-term strategy: prioritize adoption and value creation now, and monetize later when the business model supports it.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting Airtable growth focus from revenue to users
quotes.text: In that case, you might actually prefer to delay revenue for months or quarters or years to manifest it later, and when that's the case, your growth team should be fully aligned in lockstep with sales and with go-to-market team and focusing on user growth is actually the right call.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A practical alignment rule for product-led sales: if revenue is intentionally delayed, optimize for user growth and coordinate tightly with GTM.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting Airtable growth focus from revenue to users
quotes.text: In general, I would say having stability in north star metric for at least six months feels like table stakes to me and that's for the reasons that I cited before, for building momentum, for building domain expertise, and also for compounding impact in areas where you see success, where you notice growth flywheels that you can optimize.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A clear operating guideline for metric changes: keep a north star stable long enough to build momentum and compound wins.

quotes.topic_title: Shifting Airtable growth focus from revenue to users
quotes.text: A north star metric should really be a measure of what you plan to do, the strategy you plan to deliver is delivering results for the business on the other side, rather than the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: choose a north star as an output measure of strategy execution, not an input that dictates strategy prematurely.

quotes.topic_title: Reverse trial: combining freemium with a trial
quotes.text: So, with all that in mind, personally I'm in the camp of offering a reverse trial. Funky name, but what that means is offer a trial but also offer freemium. Do both.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Defines the “reverse trial” model as a concrete packaging strategy: combine freemium with a time-boxed premium trial.

quotes.topic_title: Reverse trial: combining freemium with a trial
quotes.text: That is the beauty of a free trial. It's not just that someone can try your product without paying. It's that they can try even more of the product, all of the premium, amazing advanced offerings that could be possible if they decide they want to settle on a premium plan.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Reframes trials as a deliberate premium-value showcase window, not merely a risk-free test.

quotes.topic_title: Reverse trial: combining freemium with a trial
quotes.text: When you are deciding if this is something you want to do, I would actually take a big step back from looking at competitive pricing pages and getting into the details and reading blogs and just think about what your philosophy is as a business on monetizing customers.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Gives a decision-making method: start from monetization philosophy rather than copying competitor pricing mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Reverse trial: combining freemium with a trial
quotes.text: The reason for this is generally the reason to offer a free plan or a free trial but really a free plan, the freemium type of pricing model is if you value letting millions, tens of millions of customers give your product a try, even if they never pay you a dollar.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Clarifies the strategic tradeoff behind freemium: prioritize massive adoption and brand exposure even with many non-paying users.

quotes.topic_title: Reverse trial: combining freemium with a trial
quotes.text: I like the reverse trial because user growth is important and if you're in a long game where you're trying to grow a business for a decade or more, ideally you're trying to get millions of people onto your product and you can always have that monetization conversation later, but you only get a couple moments where you can say, "Hey, pull out your credit card or let's get on the phone and talk about an enterprise contract," with a customer before you lose trust or lose patience.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Offers a long-term growth mental model: optimize early for value/loyalty because you have limited “asks” before trust and patience erode.

quotes.topic_title: Common onboarding trap: teaching features, not user value
quotes.text: I do see a very common trap that I would love to caution against, which is that employees of a company build onboarding for customers, but they build what they think customers want rather than what customers actually want, and that manifests in an onboarding experience that's not very helpful.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Highlights a core onboarding failure mode: designing from internal assumptions instead of real user needs.

quotes.topic_title: Common onboarding trap: teaching features, not user value
quotes.text: One is naming features.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Introduces a specific, common pattern to avoid when building onboarding flows.

quotes.topic_title: Common onboarding trap: teaching features, not user value
quotes.text: So, imagine you're using Airtable for the first time and you see a tooltip and it says, "This is automations," and it explains what automations is to you.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of feature-labeled onboarding that can miss the user's context and intent.

quotes.topic_title: Common onboarding trap: teaching features, not user value
quotes.text: We've named a feature, but it's really sort of an announcement of something awesome that Airtable built, rather than an application that can help educate the user on how they'll receive more value from that feature.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Reframes feature-first onboarding as internal marketing rather than value education for the user.

quotes.topic_title: Common onboarding trap: teaching features, not user value
quotes.text: Try not to name features.
quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.context: Provides a clear, actionable rule of thumb for designing onboarding around user value rather than product terminology.
